org.schwering.evi.core
Interface IModule

All Known Subinterfaces:
IConfigurable
All Known Implementing Classes:
Test
public interface IModule

Basis interface for modules.
This interface must be implemented by all modules. It forces them to provide the core functionalities: creating and destroying module instances.

Note #1: Modules need to define a constructor for being instantiated. This constructor must take one argument whose type is IParent. An example constructor would be:

	public Constructor(IParent owner) { ... }


Note #2: Modules might want to be parameterizable for being interactive with other modules. To achieve this, you need to define a second constructor which takes two arguments: first the IParent and second a Object[]. This array is intended to store the arguments. To create a parameterized module you should take a look at ModuleFactory.newInstance(ModuleContainer, IParent, Object[]). An example constructor would be:
	public Constructor(IParent owner, Object[] arguments) { ... }


Note #3: Unfortunately, at the moment the type of the first argument of the constructor(s) must really be IParent. It must not be a class implementing IParent. It must explicitely be IParent. However, you might cast it to the type of your choice later in the constructor, of course.


Note #4: This interface requires all implementing classes to define a method dispose. This method should never be invoked directly! Instead, there is ModuleFactory.disposeInstance(IModule) which not only invokes this dispose method but also cares about some internal things.

Author:
Christoph Schwering (mailto:schwering@gmail.com)
See Also:
ModuleLoader, ModuleContainer, ModuleFactory

Method Summary
 void dispose()
          Should clean up used resources when the module is shut down.
 

Method Detail

dispose

public void dispose()
Should clean up used resources when the module is shut down. For example, this method should close opened streams and files. This method should never be invoked directly! Instead, there is ModuleFactory.disposeInstance(IModule) which not only invokes this dispose method but also cares about some internal things.

See Also:
ModuleFactory.disposeInstance(IModule)
